New Records: The Chicago White Sox tied the modern major league record for losses in a season with 120 losses, matching the 1962 New York Mets.
Key Match Events: Andrew Benintendi delivered the go-ahead hit for the second time in as many games with a 10th-inning single to left-center against José Quijada.
Korey Lee gave the White Sox a 2-0 lead with a two-run homer in the second.
Lenyn Sosa put Chicago back on top with a tiebreaking solo drive in the fourth against José Suarez.
The Angels had runners on the corners in the seventh against Enyel De Los Santos but came away empty-handed when Kevin Pillar grounded into a double play.
Pre-Game Insights: Manager Grady Sizemore said the White Sox chose to have ace Garrett Crochet start against the playoff-contending Tigers because “it’s gonna make for good baseball.”
Post-Match Reflections: The White Sox avoided a record-breaking 121st loss for the second straight game, beating the Los Angeles Angels 4-3 on Wednesday night.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Angels matched a franchise record with their 95th loss, a mark shared by the 1968 and 1980 teams.
White Sox starter Davis Martin gave up two runs and three hits in 3 2/3 innings, walking a career-high five and hitting a batter before exiting with the bases loaded in the fourth.
Others: The White Sox passed the American League record of 119 losses at San Diego on Saturday and matched the ’62 Mets the following day.
The White Sox opted to push ace Garrett Crochet's start back a day to Friday.
